user_review: The take a lot of care with the way the food is prepared. It's a basic menu, but always tasty and a good meal.

Definitely one of the best poutine in town. Crispy fries, squeaky cheese that squeaks, the right amount of appetizing gravy. We visited on a beautiful autumn day at the beginning of the second wave of the pandemic. The guys  were allowing customers one by one inside and handing out orders through the side window. The park across the street served us as a perfect dining room. Beside delicious poutine the selection of solid local beers was wonderful. Awesome place to experience this loved traditional Quebec dish!

My brother and I dropped by to try their fish burger, which was recommended by a friend of ours. Rather than a burger, it was more like a slider in size. The fish filet was lightly breaded and served in a white roll with homemade tartar sauce. It tasted similar to an upgraded version of McD's filet-o-fish, but fresher and less greasy. Overall, a nice mid-day snack for $3.

2.5 starsHeard a lot about this place and everytime i pass by it. It seemed busy.Place looks like an interesting fast food joint.I was disapointed in the food though,i took the fish burger with poutine and salad.The fish sandwich had potential, but the fish was so flat and squished,if it was a little bit thicker ,it would have been way better. The poutine was quite sad as well,fries were nothing special,not crispy just kinda sad.sauce was typical and cheese also.With the name patati patata i would have expected fried to be at leat similar to frite alors.Finally the salad surprisingly was the best thing out of the 3 things. I don't think i would go backm
Awesome place. Came here for the classic poutine. Was absolutely delicious. Highly recommend.

After hearing about this spot for years and living five mins away from it, we finally decided to pick up Burgers with sides of Fries and Poutine for dinner. Unfortunately this turned out to be one of those over hyped places, with extremely average food. The quality and taste could be and should be improved. A burger with cheese and a side ended up costing the same as any other burger joint serving food of excellent quality and taste! Will not recommend this spot.

Worth every bite. This dingy little corner houses a needle in the haystack and the poutine is to die for. Come late night, early morning- or absolutely ANYTIME you are craving something extra Montreal. You won't regret it!

The regular poutine is amazing... the second best I've ever had. Small place and very charming. The staff is super friendly. If I lived in this neighborhood I would get food from here multiple times a week. Not overpriced. Love it.P.S. had it on Wednesday, then after the bar on Saturday night - we added a stop to our Uber to pick up some poutine. The Uber driver was not happy, but we were :)

Living in Maine and growing up in a French Canadian community, I'm no stranger to poutine. It's pretty much a staple of my winter diet. However, most places where I live don't make it vegetarian friendly (they use meat juices for the gravy), so I was delighted to find several places in Montreal that do.Patati Patata hit the spot, and there was much to love about it: being open until the wee hours of the morning not just on weekends, but every day; offering up vegetarian options (you can get the traditional poutine with gravy and cheese curds, or their patatine which also comes with sautéed peppers and onions on top); the price (6.95) for the portion is amazing (I left feeling just the right amount of full); and, I don't know why, but the single salty olive plopped right in the center of my mountain of crispy shoe string fries, creamy gravy, and squeaky curds was perfection (they're on to something here with this).Yes, it's a suuuuuuuuuuper small place; if you're coming alone, you *might* be able to snag a spot inside. Even coming as a pair, you could *possibly* squeeze in (and people literally do squeeze into every inch of this space, every hour to eat - be prepared for constant friendly bumping into). I think takeaway is probably the way to go!

I am glad that I found this place and it's really close to my apartment. They have the best burger in a best price in the city I would say. I love the small cozy interior, and the friendliness of staffs. I had been there couple of times already, and was never disappointed. Would highly recommend this place to everyone! :)

This place was just alright to me.We tried a gauntlet of their poutines. The classic was definitely the best. Can't go wrong with crispy fries, squeeky cheese curds, and thick gravy.The one with onions and mushrooms and bell pepper sounded great on paper, but when we opened it up, our mirepoix seemed to have just been added to the poutine raw. Not even a hint of butter or salt on the onion/mushroom/bell pepper, which were just tossed into what had been a classic poutine.Finally, there was the smoked meat poutine. Nothin' wrong with it, totally fine, but my perception of the smoked meat may have been colored by my recent visit to Schwartz's. It added to the poutine, but not in a way that was really memorable.Altogether, this place is solid, but just didn't hold up to the other poutineries I'd visited over the course of the week.

A friend of ours brought us to this place for a bite to go.The good: Outside decor is stunning and catchy. Very cozy and charming. Super duper cheap in prices. All the vegetables are fresh. Friendly cashier. Food is great!The bad: Limited seating (like 10 chairs). Lots of people waiting inside (and outside) for takeout. They mixed up the order of my wife's burger, which was very disappointing since it was very basic. Ketchup for takeout is simply impossible. Can get noisy. Can get congested since everyone is waiting for their order.Expect to wait, and go for taking on the go. But worth it since the food is great and prices are cheap.
Loved it, fries were fresh and crispy, gravy was A+ tasty, curds were squeaky and springy and the people working there were very nice!

So came to Montreal with one thing in mind. POUTINE.A friend recommended Patati Patata and of course, every website/blog/anything ever written about Montreal recommend la Banquise. We were staying at an AirBnB literally 2 seconds away on St. Laurent during the mural festival. The best! I think they were open even later than their regular business hours during that time. As everyone has said, it's a small place, but if you're lucky to grab a seat and even if you're not it's well worth your time. The poutine was lovely. Crispy string fries, a ton of gravy and cheese curds, and slight olive flavor here. I shared a plate with my partner and he let me have the last few bites. Throw away your healthy, conscious eating habits here. It's time to dig into poutine!

Best poutine we had in our entire trip! The staff were friendly and amazing, everything we ordered was delicious and exceeded our expectations. This is a very small diner but the food felt wholesome, the poutine was fresh, the fries stayed crispy right down to the bottom even though it had gravy and cheese going in every crevice. We ordered a mushroom and pepper poutine, with a tofu sandwich which. The tofu in this sandwich was well flavoured, and I haven't enjoyed vegetarian fare like this in a long time from a restaurant that doesn't focus on vegetarian cuisine. These people really know how to satisfy your taste buds! Thanks guys for the best meal we've had on our road trip!

Squeakiest cheese curds ever. One of the qualifiers of authentic poutine is not just cheese curds, but squeaky cheese curds. I thought I knew what that was and have eaten poutine around Quebec a few times before, but this was on another level. I'm pretty sure other people in the room (I got them to go) could hear the squeak as I ate.I have to be honest however, the curds were almost squeaky beyond my preference. That speaks more to what I like rather than the quality and authenticity of the place and they're probably deserving of '5' stars, but I can't just bring myself to it if I wasn't fully in love with it.With all that said: I still enjoyed it and the quality of everything  - fries and gravy too - were great.They actually have a reasonably large menu, so poutine isn't the only thing here. Prices looked reasonable and they even had borscht for somewhere around $4. I saw someone eating that in the restaurant and it looked quite good.

Super tiny shop but friendly staff and yummy poutine. Not really my kind of resto but after seeing the amazing reviews, we decided to give it a try since we were close by! Got the classic poutine and it was big enough to share! The olives on top were a nice touch. We were seated by the window so we had the perfect view of windy Montreal while we were eating.

Patati Patata is located on a street corner and the small restaurant is the epitome of a hole in the wall spot with bar stool seating with a clear view into the compact kitchen and a few two top and window counter seats.  The ambiance is casual and old school with a menu posted on the wall for both lunch and for dinner.  The draw is definitely the bargain prices, good eats, and comfort food with poutine, burgers, and sandwiches being their go to fare.  Our order:Grilled Cheese Sandwich - $5.  Melted on the grill and pressed with a panini press, the sandwich was crispy, tasty, and gooey...all good things. Onion Soup - $5. A simple but well-executed version with well caramelized and sweet soft onions in a savory broth with just the right amount of cheese and croutons. Poutine - $6.95.  As classic a preparation as it gets with French Fries, squeaky cheese curds, and gravy.  Honestly, the French fries could have been a bit fresher, but mix the gravy in well with the cheese curds and fries and it was better.  Not my favorite poutine, but ok.  To me, the key to poutine is gravy, the more and hotter the better.  But I'm not Canadian so take that with a grain of salt. Overall, Patati Patata is a bargain and worthwhile spot.  The onion soup was excellent, especially at the price point, and the sandwich and poutine were tasty and filling.  The burgers look good for next time as well. Patati Patata accepts credit cards including Amex.

I've passed by Patati Patata for years and it's been on my bucket list for a long time. There's always a line up and it's worth the wait ( coming from someone who doesn't do line ups). We decided to stop there on a Saturday for lunch and were quite satisfied. I had the burger with a classic Poutine and asked to add mushrooms. The Poutine was really delicious and the fries were tasty and crunchy. Their burger too was delicious. You have the option of adding fries and salad with burger as well as replacing your fries with a Poutine. As well, you have the option of customizing your burgers. I hear the Patitine ( Poutine with onions, peppers) is supposedly really good so if you feel adventurous go ahead with that. For an extremely reasonable price each person can eat for under $10.The staff is super friendly and very accommodating. We were lucky enough to sit by the big window and enjoy the sun and people watch. Overall great experience and I will be back.
Very good poutine!  Very small place though. If you order extra cheese it will come with a lot of cheese! So make sure you like it!

This place is not changing the game or anything but if you want some yummy late night, post-bar eats this is the place to be! The poutine was really solid and our food was ready in no time! I'll definitely be back next time I'm in Montreal!

+1 on agreeing that their poutine has crispy fries.We wanted to try a poutine place that was more like a local gem and I think we found it!LOCATION & DECOR: 4/5Okay this place is pretty small. It has about two tables and a few bar seats. The inside and outside of this restaurant is colourful and funky. It's conveniently located right on St Laurent, and is a perfect place to go ANY time of day for poutine or burgers!FOOD: 5/5I love poutine but I think eating a $15 poutine per person is ridiculous. I appreciate that they have a normally sized poutine for $6.95. Their fries are CRISPY, and their cheese curds are super squeaky. It's an amazing classic poutine. They also have burgers for $3~ which is insanely cheap. Also have fish and tofu burger options. SERVICE: 4/5There was one chef and one server here. They were friendly but seemed overwhelmed with the amount of duties they had to do. It's understandable though since it's a small but very busy/fast paced place.Definitely would come again to their their other foods!

Very good place for vegans/vegetarians. They only have mushroom gravy for poutine! Fries are delicious, as is the tofu burger. Nice place to sit and people watch (though there is very limited seating.) Excellent music, great prices. Cool little spot!

Of all the meals I had on my last trip to Montreal -- and there were many -- this one seemed the MOST Montreal. The most live-like-a-local, the most iconic. When I close my eyes and think about that trip, this is the first meal that comes to mind and the one that will be with me the longest.My late night walk through the hot and humid streets had taken me across town, and I had just enjoyed some really fine ice cream (sorbet, to be precise) and I was just wandering the streets watching people and taking in the sights and sounds. It was a Thursday night, but the sidewalks were full of life even at the midnight hour. I was coming down the street and noticed Patati Patata on the other side, and immediately remembered it from the Yelp app as a place I had bookmarked to try if I was ever in the area. Late night poutine, I had noted. Well, I was in the area and was definitely down for late night poutine.I made my way in and they were able to seat me at the counter immediately. There's not much seating at all, so don't bring your big groups here unless you're doing takeaway. That's actually a great option and one I saw plenty of people doing. This is late night post-bar or between-bar grub and you can take it to enjoy elsewhere, even to one of the nearby parks that seems to be teeming with people even into the dark hours of night.I sat at the counter and ordered my poutine, turned to the dining room and the view of the street, and watched the busy boulevard and all the wonders of Montreal unfold before me. Laughing groups, a young woman flanked on both sides by two friends of totally different description, couples looking dressy, kids from college flirting; I had a front row seat to Montreal.The poutine arrived shortly, and with an incredible soundtrack overhead (seriously, it was '80s music and I was jamming) I plucked the olive off the top and popped it into my mouth before devouring the fries, curds, and gravy in my dish. It was hot, fresh, and the crew behind the counter including a very thin and smiling young woman let me know it was served with nothing but love and respect for their late night followers. I paid them the paltry sum for such an experience, and made my way back out to the street, and continued drifting down the boulevard, eventually making my way back to the apartment I was renting and laying down with a belly full of poutine and a mind full of Montreal nightlife.

I found this place while searching for "cheap eats Montréal" and this was the cheapest of the eats I found--that was actually good! For ~$14 CAD I got a burger (with added cheese) and added poutine and a salad and 2 beers. It was 100% worth it. I got there around lunch time, just before the rush and I really enjoyed watching the one grill cook bang out all of the dishes and cook everything to order. I sat right at the counter and was privy to everyone's conversations, their orders as well as everything going on outside, too. Now, this place is SMALL. Probably 400 sq ft of space total, including the WC. As far as the food goes, it was just okay. I had my first Canadian poutine here and it was truly just okay. There were fries, curds and gravy, but it was sincerely just that. No frills. The burger was on a very cheap bun but it was also $2.50, so I am not complaining--just stating lolI'd eat here again if I were in the Saint-Laurent 'hood. Just know that if/when you go, there may be a line out the door, but it will move quickly.

I'm no poutine expert and am def. not Canadian, but I still know how to differentiate between crispy and non crispy fries. And I'm giving 2 rather than 1 stars strictly because I don't know how a "great" poutine should taste. My honest experience prob. is closer to a 1 because I did not enjoy my dish at all.A lot of reviews raved about Patati Patata's fries being crispy til the end with all the cheese curds and gravy on top. Uh, no? At least not for us. Even the naked fries with no gravy or cheese curds on top of them were limp and a bit stale. Gravy was also watery and the *touch* of olive flavoring was overwhelming.

Hole-in-the-wall restaurants have a special place in my heart, and Patati Patata is a corner in a wall that makes great food. They occupy a small corner space on a busy popular street and do comfort diner items. I think their whole operation consists of the bar area that surround the open kitchen... and that's it.We got the patatine to go and sat outside to dig into our poutine topped with onions, mushrooms and peppers. There were plenty of squeaky cheese curds and every fry found a bit of gravy to dress itself with. The peppers and onions gave a bright fresh flavor that broke up the heavy flavors of gravy and cheese. A quick and yummy pick-me-up meal as you explore this area.

Small, cozy, friendly little spot with good quality food at a reasonable price. We dropped in just to try their poutine (we actually got the "patatine" with raw mushrooms and onions and peppers), and it was very good, but I was also tempted to try the borscht, fresh pressed juice, or crepes (which looked really tasty.)

This place is a TINY little restaurant at a street corner. Patati Patata is definitely known for their fries for good reason. They know just how to fry them up! I've also had their beef burger and tofu burger. I personally found the tofu burger incredibly bland and would not recommend. However, I do suggest trying out their other menu items! Best part is each order is only a couple of dollars and it won't break your bank to try out new things. The cook is very nice and tries his best to accommodate you with what little space they already have in the resto. However, I do recommend getting take out or coming during quiet hours as its very cramped.

This was my first experience with poutine, and I was not let down. I can't believe it took me so long to try it and now I can confidently say I have a new favorite place to go when visiting Montreal. Very reasonably priced, a couple burgers and plate of poutine with a pitcher of the house made iced tea is perfect for two and won't break the bank. The employees were super patient with us, considering we didn't know a single word of French, and they made ordering very easy. I will recommend this place to anyone going into town, absolutely worth the trip.

For this type of place it's as good as it gets. The staff is amazing, they make you feel welcome whether you speak French or English. The food is always fresh and delicious. The draught beer (and a cider) selection offers something for everyone. The prices are more than fair. Open late, accepts credit cards, They rock..

THE BEST POUTINE EVER. It's easy the best thing I ate in Montreal. So flavorful and there are plenty of cheese curds. The have other toppings, but I prefer the original. It's just so dang tasty. The gravy just happens to be vegetarian, which is nice. I also had an orange grapefruit juice that was delicious. There might be a wait because the restaurant is small, but it's worth it!

We walked all over city and my friend who is a local suggested making a stop here. This was perfect. The staff were so kind and funny. The food hit the spot and is a great for a lunch stop. It does get crowded but that just adds to the atmosphere. I strongly recommend making a stop here.

ATMOSPHERE: Patati Patata is a very small restaurant on the corner of St-Laurent. It has a rather "vintage" ambiance. In my opinion it is quite cramped but it wasn't unbearable. I would recommend coming at quiet hours.FOOD: The food was very good and the quality was okay. But it's comfort food so I wasn't expecting a high-class meal. I got the Tofu burger (which I would not recommend) but my friend got the cheeseburger and it seemed pretty tasty. The fries were decent as well.PRICE: Honestly, you won't find cheaper than this, especially for the quantity/quality that you're getting. Portions aren't the biggest but that's normal for this kind of place. Burgers are around 2-3$ and fries as well. I'd rather come here than go to McDonalds for sure. SERVICE: The service was very nice. It had a "family-owned" restaurant feel to it. The main chef was pretty sweet and efficient.

As a Montrealer born and raised, I've had my fair share of poutine. Although I shouldn't be allowed to pick favourites because all poutine is great, Patati Patata has a special place in my heart. Their poutine might possibly be the best in Montréal. They have shoe string fries and the most perfect combination of vegetables on their Patatine. The fresh veggies cut through the heaviness of an otherwise heavy meal. I'd recommend this place over and over and never regret coming here!

I wanted to try this place after people rated it for having the best poutine unfortunately I disagree! The fries were small and skinny it tasted more like Macdonald's fries, I prefer freshly cut fries! Honestly nothing special wouldn't even make a trip back here!

Poutine is their main deal, and it was pretty good.  Want some poutine a bit more fancy?  They do that as well.  Burgers and hot dogs were also on the menu but didn't look that exciting.  Its a small place, get in, don't waste their time, order, eat, get out.

I have been here a couple times to take out food and once now to sit down. Really like this place for a cheap bite!Food: really good, they definitely don't skimp on portion size and it's really good comfort food. I've had burgers, poutine, and sandwiches here and have enjoyed everything I've tried here so far.Service: really fast for a small place with three guys working it. When you sit down, there's little interaction but that's to be expected. If it's busy, there's a park nearby to sit down and eat at.Price: cheap and worth it. Great value and makes a good quick dinner solution. Easily can finish under $10 with a large BLT, salad, fries.Ambiance: looks cute and very local feeling. Sitting down in such a small space is tight but nice in the summer with the windows open.

I little mom and pop shop that specializes on no frills sandwiches and Poutine. The portions are smaller than normal, which is fine for me. The prices are cheap and the service was humble and friendly. The restaurant is quaint with bar stool settings overlooking a small kitchen. I enjoyed my light dinner of tofu burger and poutine. For less than $10 i left pretty satisfied. I had observed a lot of take out orders and as I saw people coming and going i knew i made the right choice by stopping in and grabbing a bite before my flight home to LA the next day. Thanks for the hospitality--it was wonderful!

This review is for 3.5 stars.Patali was ok and always packed, but I felt that the poutine fell below the high standards of the city.  The fries were very thin as opposed to the potato-goodness of most poutine in the city.  And I don't enjoy the squeaky cheese curds, which Patati does especially loud.  With other options just around the block (in all honesty on every block on Montreal) I would keep walking and try poutine somewhere else.  Patati is not bad by any stretch, but it's different.
One of those overhyped Yelp spot. Average food, really really salty. Service is not something to write home about either. Meh.

This is definitely a popular spot for poutine. I had to wait a good 10 mins in line. The line was sort of confusing as it was a mix of people who were waiting for their order and people who still needed to order. It wasn't much of a line as it was a crowd of people just hanging at the entrance of the restaurant as this place is super tiny.I got the poutine and burger for about $12.50 taxes in. The burger was quite small, and the poutine was about the size of a personal size poutine. I had this for take out as the bar was full of people. Actually a lot of people do take out for this reason, and eat at the park nearby. They do not skimp on the curds...I have to say I got a very healthy helping of cheese in my poutine. I found the gravy to have a unique flavour. It tasted like olives. I actually found the gravy to be too salty for my taste though... The burger I was thoroughly disappointed. I do not recommend getting burgers here. The burger was sandwiched between two dry buns and the patty was super salty and dry. Go for the poutine!

We were hungry, saw the pretty colours of Patati Patata's storefront, then walked in for dinner.This is a very small restaurant, that can only fit a handful of people. Don't bother bringing a group unless if you guys are doing takeout. That being said, bring one friend along, have a seat, and enjoy watching your food be prepared right in front of you.This time around, I flipped the script and ordered a fish burger and a tofu burger. Both are served with a large slice of tomato, green leaf lettuce, and red onion, on a basic white bun. The fish burger was all well and good, but what stuck in my mind was hands down the tofu burger. We all know that tofu is generally just about tasteless, but they marinate these patties in what must be unicorn tears, because they come out so well flavoured that I wouldn't be mad at cutting meat from my diet for an extended period. I also got a side of poutine, which was simple, with classic gravy, cheese curds, and a single black olive, (just for fun).I'm really glad that we stopped by this tiny little fry shop, and I suggest you do too.

Ok.  You guys gotta go and experience why 4 stars.  Suffice to say being vegetarian we were well looked after and the food is delicious. Tofu burger well done and tasty. BLT non vege is awesome.My tofu burger with spicy sauce we also superb.

Disclaimer: This review is based on two vastly different experiences that I've had with the poutine here. The first time I had it was for takeout a little under a year ago, and unfortunately, it was pretty awful. While the fries were deliciously crisp and held the gravy and cheese curds well, the gravy was so salty and olive-y that I couldn't even finish it. I swore I would never go there again, but out of curiosity, I decided to give it another chance.When I went there recently, I decided to eat in, and upon first bite, it actually tasted really good. Perhaps it was because I was famished, but I finished off the whole plate without losing my appetite. Maybe it has to do with the fact that the gravy, when put on a plate, has more room to spread out and evenly distribute itself among the fries than when it's just sitting on top of them in a box, but it had a unique flavor to it that made it quite addictive. I left feeling very satisfied and content with my experience.So, long story short, it's probably best to eat Patati Patata's poutine inside, as it will be much tastier, easier to digest, and feel less like salt overkill than if you take it to go.

We are a family of 5 and happened to pass by this little place. Didn't look like it would be very good from the outside but we were very happily surprised, as it was fantastic! We are pescatarian and the poutine was vegetarian and it was so good. They have a wide variety of foods and everything was homemade and delicious. Great service too. It is a tiny place and it was packed with people coming in all the time and I see why.

We came here to try the poutine, which some of us realized we aren't quite fans of though the French fries were delicious! But what was extremely good and I'll never forget is the fresh squeezed orange and grapefruit juice I had! Five stars for that! The guy we ordered from recommended it and it was the first time I was ever offered to have both mixed together. I wish I could have another glass right now. It wasn't too sweet and wasn't too sour and was just the perfect refresher after the long walk we'd had.

Went here at like 1am on a Saturday night. I ordered the poutine and a fish burger. The fish burger was alright, nothing special, but honestly the poutine was the best that I've had in Montreal so far. I wasn't expecting it to be this good. It was better than, Shwartzs or La Basques to be honest. I'll definitely be back for the poutine. Also the service here is amazing. Super chill dudes behind the counter.

We travelled over 2km on foot just for their poutine and it did not disappoint. Ordered the hamburger with poutine and salad and was amazed by everything here. The salad was extremely fresh and the burger was customisable, which was a major plus for someone who has lots of allergies. The diner was small and cozy, so I would suggest coming here as a party of 2, or just order takeout. The staff were so friendly and our server had the most infectious laugh! We don't speak French, but the staff were more than happy to translate the menu and speak in English. Overall, a fantastic place to eat and we will be coming back here the next time we are in Montréal. TL;DR: Amazing. Absolutely amazing.

I came here in Summer 2013 (twice) and I loved it!  Their prices are very reasonable and I ordered take out twice because I didn't want to wait for a table.  The restaurant is very small and can only seat up to around 15 people I believe.The burgers are very cheap (I believe around two bucks) so ordering two will fill you up easily.  Their fish burger is also very tasty and their poutine is decent.  The walk from central Montreal is perhaps 15-25 minutes so I feel like it's worth it since there is a lot to see on the way to this restaurant.The restaurant is actually pretty hard to spot because the name is kind of hidden so you might want to look it up on google images to prepare yourself. (or just use GPS on your phone if you have data)  Patati Patata is the epitome of the term  "cheap eats" and definitely should be visited by anybody, not only people on a budget!

We came here on a friends recommendation to try out the Poutine. This cute little restaurant has limited seating but the server was really good at juggling people around and also very nice to us. We were seated in about 15 minutes. We ordered the patatine which is a vegetarian poutine, and a couple of burgers on the side. The burgers are more like sliders and really cheap as well. I ordered the tofu burger and got a really filling piece for  under 3$. The poutine itself was way better than what I tried once in the US so I was glad I ordered it. The crowd was mostly local and the menu is in French but everyone speaks English and people were very friendly and helpful. Metered parking on the street which is as good as it gets for Montreal.
good burgers and good poutine. if you're hungry and wanna have something fast and not greasy, cause fast food can sometimes be like that, go here. prices are also good

I came here specifically for poutine and I was a little disappointed. The french fries were a bit overdone and the gravy somewhat too salty. Unfortunately, I've had better poutine in Vancouver. However, I did like the cramped coziness of the restaurant and the friendliness of the staff. And the price is very economical. Would I come here again for poutine? probably not. Would I come again to try something else the next time I'm in Montreal? perhaps. Their omelettes looked pretty appetizing.

Delicious poutine!Super tiny place but the line moves quickly. If you can't find a spot, order to go.We waited for about 5 minutes and snagged a seat at the window. Ordered one poutine each with a Boreal IPA beer - such a great combination!The (vegetarian!) gravy was the right amount of salty, cheese curds were optimally squeaky, and the fries stayed crispy until the last bite. They also serve the dish topped with one black olive (I love olives so much, this was amazing!).Perfect poutine in my opinion. Would return next time I visit Montreal.

This is a tastey, divey, and generally awesome spot to grab a late night bite. Nothing fancy, just super salty poutine and sliders that you order by filling out a tiny slip of paper. They have 3 beers on draft and maybe 8 seats total in the place. It's grungy and full of interesting people after midnight. I love it and keep going back.
Good poutine, good atmosphere, good service. I like it here, even though it's small :)

We went here on our last morning in Montreal and get the vegan breakfast. It was a HUGE meal for an incredible price that even included coffee. The waiters there were soooooo friendly, the interior is a quaint size and the jams they were playing were great. I wish we would've known how great it was earlier, because then we would have gone before to try the poutine.

The burgers here are like little flavour bombs! You can't eat just one. The restaurant is a tiny hole in the wall with very limited seating. If you eat in they will bring your order to your table. You can also order beer! Ordering is simple, if you get a burger you are handed a small paper with the various toppings offered. You write down your name and check off what toppings you want and then pay for your order. The wait is usually pretty fast (about 5-10 minutes) considering they're always very busy! I always eat at the park across the street since seating is tight and the restaurant gets really hot with all the bodies inside. The poutine was also good but a little too salty. Seriously, the burgers are all you need to fall in love with Patati Patata. The location is also great for a post or pre-drinks snack, with tons of bars within walking distance. Service is friendly. I'm not sure about parking since I always just uber or walk here.

Patati Patata is along St. Laurent, next to an open park. It features open windows and views of the busy street. A tiny location, what it lacks in counter space it makes up for in quality, flavor, and service.I came to Montreal with a mission of finding poutine, and this place delivered. My last day in Montreal, I rolled in on a Saturday around 10 a.m. and was able to get a seat right away at the bar. I ordered the hamburger with poutine and salad and a Saint Justin mineral water. The hamburger is cooked well and about the size of a regular McDonald's kid's meal hamburger. A little bigger than a slider, but not much (you add toppings by selecting them from a checklist, but it's all in French). It was really the perfect size, though, as the salad is ample and fresh with onion, cabbage, carrot, greek olive and tomato, and the poutine takes up a third or more of the plate.And let's talk about the poutine. The fresh french fries are smothered in squeaky white cheese curds and smothered with brown gravy and topped with a single kalamata olive. It's delicious and wholly satisfying, especially after a long night drinking and before a long flight home. The staff were friendly and accommodating and the price was less than I thought it was going to be. A really great place, and I would definitely come here again. Magnifique!

This eclectic looking casse-croute shop on saint-Laurent serves some of the tastiest cheap bites in the city. Famous for their poutine, which they serve with a cute olive on top, and their inexpensive burgers.The poutine is saucy, spiced the right way, at the right temperature. Sometimes when poutine is served too hot, it melts the cheese away, when it is served too cold, the curds are always squishy, which means they are fresh. The burger are extremely inexpensive, and they are very tasty. This place is absolutely awesome.Oh, they also have a liquor license and they serve beer, which is awesomer.

This is a very nice vegetable poutine. The fries are soft and well seasoned. The vegetables are just a bit raw for my liking on a hot dish. The gravy is smooth and fresh tasting (not chalky like some junky poutine.) The cheese is fresh.Overall this was a good poutine and the service was fun and friendly. They've got a nice shop going in this small corner of Rachel and St. Laurent.

Best poutine in Montreal! We even had the one in the much hyped Le Banquise and felt this one was faaar better! Great service too! We tried the veggie omelette and the patatine. It is a small and delicious place! Must visit!

My boyfriend and i wanted to try a new poutine place so we stepped in and ordered. The man asked us if we wanted to sit down or take out. Since it was 11:30pm we figured we'd probably take some home anyways. We asked to have in a to go box but we would sit there to eat; less dishes to do and more environmentally friendly. "Could we have it to go but eat here instead?""Thats exactly what i dont want. Its only for here or take out."With that tone of voice, i'm boycotting that place and he will never take a dime from me. Ive done customer service for 10 years and thats surely not how you make clients feel welcome. I guess im better off giving my money to a poutine place that actually deserves it before acting all pretentious.

We came here solely for the poutine! Reviews said this was one of the best in Montreal, and I must say we enjoyed it thoroughly. The gravy wasn't too salty (although we do wish we had more of it) and the fries were crispy to the last bite.  Most importantly, I think I finally know what "squeaky" curds are, and they're delicious!

This is a great neighborhood poutine shop.  A pretty extensive menu - I had the poutine with roast beef - it was well priced albeit a bit basic.  It was tasty with the most cheese curds of the four places we tried while we were in town.  The regular poutine was delicious as well, thin cut fries with light grave and white curds.It's not fancy, not big inside, so plan to wait for a seat.  On a Tuesday at noon, we were able to get seated right away but it probably gets busy.They have a couple of beers on tap and the prices are right.  The servers was friendly and super fast.  We also appreciated that he helped us find the nearest bus route for our next adventure.

My first time in Montreal and trying poutine was a must. After much research on my fav foodie site, Yelp of course, Patati Patata was in my crosshairs. Now, I am biased, I needed to find a veggie friendly poutine. I was with locals and they were a bit skeptical of this variation. However, the fries, gravy, and cheese curds were delicious and just left you wanting more! The saltiness of the fries and richness of the gravy balanced out nicely with the mild tasting cheese curds. The place is absolutely tiny, so if you can't get a table, order to go. There is a nice little park across the street and you can dine al fresco if it's not too icy cold. Thanks Patati for my first taste of your native specialty, poutine!

A tiny luncheonette with an eye-catchingly blue exterior and a few tricks up its sleeve.  Inside it's little more than a counter with a few other seats around it--room maybe 20 in total.  I came here for the poutine, but noticed they also serve borscht, so I got that as an appetizer.The borscht was more a creamy soup than the hearty vegetable soup you might be expecting, and it was beautifully beety.  The poutine was... poutine.  The fries were fresh--I saw them fried in front of me on the opposite side of the counter--and were offered with an optional salad on the side, which I got and which made me feel better about eating this for dinner.  It was good but I think on the topic of poutine, no matter how fresh and well-received by others, I have a heretical opinion: I prefer New Jersey disco fries.  Other details:- A fellow down the counter from me got an amazing-looking burger platter--it seemed like four burgers, not exactly small, on a plate, with some salad. This was eaten by one man.  I liked him immediately.  I wished I'd ordered this platter instead of my poutine.- It's a teeny place, again, not fine dining and maybe not a place to take a first date, but it's got charm, and the folks working behind the counter are young and exude happiness.  Anyway, it was nice to sit here a while.

The poutine is decent. We had both versions available, the one with the onions, mushrooms, and bell pepper and the classic. The person at the register was brusque, although it's given since it was still a little busy.My one star off was for the saltiness of the gravy and an awkward exchange. Usually, I tip 18-20% given the location. However, I am a new tourist with basically no French language knowledge. I was handed the card machine and accidentally put 0 tip (I had the 15, 18, 20% options pulled up for me at other locations.) The guy, upon seeing this, was understandably annoyed and condescendingly told me that tip isn't included in the price and that I should know that. I didn't have Canadian dollars on me and neither did my partner. As such, we awkwardly stood around trying to figure out what to do while feeling guilty. Otherwise, the place is pretty great.
It's a small and cozy place.When you go there you MUST try Poutine and hot dogs.Nom nom.

Simple cheap food done well! For 6.50$ I had a poutine, salads and slider!  Everything was good. I liked the in house ice tea mini pitcher we got and the tofu burger was not bad at all. The service was friendly and quick. Really cute dinner ambiance. Good cheap date night spot! I would definitely go back!
Non pretentious, amazing food & friendly service! The staff is very cool & has good recommendations. Poutine is definitely the star on the menu!
Burgers were delicious!  Grilled cheese was delicious. Small venue but perfect for takeout.

I thought the poutine here was nothing special. The cheese curds were extremely squeaky and the gravy could have used some more flavor. The building is very small. I would not recommend groups or even children. Since there was no room to sit, I ended up eating in the park right outside. Service was okay.

I visited Montreal for a bachelor party and my mission was two-fold: strippers and poutine.  I had poutine from the dingy places on the side of the streets and from the fancy restaurants with their fancy steaks.  Patati Patata stands above the rest.Simple recipe, friendly service, bumping atmosphere and delicious poutine.  What more can you ask for?  Sure it may be standing room only and the line is out there door, but these aren't necessarily bad things.  PS. who knew there were such thigns as a "poutinery"
After a day of walking this hit the spot, definitely a place to go if you want a little burger or some poutine. Also a really interesting venue as well, really cool.

Small place, really simple food but done very well. We had the poutine with mushrooms, peppers and onions and it was very tasty. The fries are thin and crispy and sort of tasted a bit like sweet potato fries but they weren't, so that was odd but still very tasty. We also had the cheeseburger. Great price for a pretty tasty burger, it's a little small but still worth it for what you get.

Love this place!  Workers are friendly and welcoming.  And they make my favourite poutine in all of Montreal (a city filled with great poutine places).  Delicious breakfasts, burgers, salads, and soups, too.  The restaurant is small and often crowded, but don't let that keep you away. Tables and seats free up quickly and the workers will do their best to find you seating as fast as they can.  Definitely a place to check out for anyone visiting Montreal.
The poutine was NOT as good as la banquise regardless of a previous comment. Stayed for an extended period for shelter from the rain, the service didn't chase us out, bless them.

One of my only disappointing meals while in Montreal. Stopped in around midnight and had a friendly guy help me interpret the French menu. I decided on a burger and poutine under the guise that it was $6.50. My French sucks so I apparently misunderstood the guy/menu and my bill ended up being like $9 instead.That wouldn't have been so bad if I a) got good service, b) liked my meal, or c) got what I ordered. The guy couldn't come out from behind the counter so I had to clean my own table since he couldn't reach.  Another no biggie but added to the experience. Got my burger first (and it was made waaaay after I ordered it) and it was just ok.  The poutine came next and it was not the one with the vegetables I asked for. But I didn't want to make a fuss. It was also just ok. I had to pretty much beg a worker to take my money as he was focused on other people. In fairness, he apologized for the price misunderstanding. But it was just overall a meh experience. I can't imagine I'll be back with so many other options in the area.

This place is so cute and cool. It is really tiny (sits maybe about 10 people in total), but it's more of a take-out place. The atmosphere is very casual place. Their menus are written on the wall, and you seat yourselves. The outside looks like something out of a comic book. So cool.It's open late so it's perfect for grabbing a late dinner or snack. I got the tofu burger with fries and a salad. The burger was $2.50, and the fries and salad was $4. Really good price for a meal. The food wasn't the best, but it was definitely worth $6.50.

NOTE: An American reviewing a Canadian EateryThis is was our 1st stop as soon as we landed in Canada and wasn't part of our original plan, though a very pleasant surprise.Parking: Street parking is available for a nominal fee. We paid $0.25 Canadian and we received 14hrs worth of parking. Admittedly, we may have paid $2.00 since we are new to the currency so prices/hr may vary.Ambiance: **** (4 stars)So say this place was small would be an overstatement. I've been in master bathrooms with more seating compacity. That said, this place had an eclectic, punk rock atmosphere to it. Since the primary language in the area is French, we were both SUPER intimidated, but the people behind and in front of the counter were inviting and helpful. Also note, the menu posted on the walls are in French so if you don't read French just ask. We took our order to go since seating was limited and only got Poutine (obviously) and a Tofu Burger.Poutine: **** (4 stars)Not knowing the difference between good and bad poutine, we really enjoyed what we consumed. There are many different variations of poutine you can purchase here but we went with 2 classic versions for our first time. One plain and one with ground sausage. Fries used in the poutine were excellent in size, similar to McDonalds fries, and were crunchy on the outside and creamy on the inside. The gravy used was flavorful and thick enough to stick to the fries without making them soggy. The cheese curds were plentiful and were around to provide texture and chew more than actual flavor. We would come back to try other variations and combos.Tofu Burger: *** (3 stars)Out of left field but it was recommended to us by a woman waiting to be seating. I would qualify this more as a sandwich with burger toppings than an actual burger. The "burger" was small. The bread used was a quarter part of french baguette, buttery and crusty. A good foundation. The condiments included mayo, tomato, red onion, grain mustard. The star of the show was the 2 chunks of marinated tofu used. They seemed to have a light curry flavor to them and the density of the tofu was a new experience to the both of us. All in all the "burger" was an experience and very enjoyable, but nothing we would be craving for back in the States.Overall: **** (4 stars)As our 1st official Poutinerie, Patati Patata has set the bar pretty high. The vibe of the place was electric and all the patrons were eating and smiling. Don't be intimidated by the French menu, the people behind the counter are more than willing to help. The food was fresh, flavorful, and inventive. Give it a try! - Kev/Mag
Definitely a good place to have breakfast, with some freshly squeezed orange juice and the blt egg sandwich was so good and worth every cheap cent!! The employees were also pretty cool :)

Finally found THE go-to place for a quick cheap bite at anytime of the day, on St-Laurent. They open late too!As a regular customer, I usually go for two burgers- the beef burger and the tofu burger. Both are great. You can choose add-ons on your burger, as the staff will hand you a sheet to mark what you want. The burgers are small but they are inexpensive. Be aware that the buns are ciabatta buns - if you're an avid fan of brioche buns. I've tried the potato fries once and they are great!Now, the atmosphere of the restaurant. A very "plateau" vibe with good service. Note that the restaurant is very small, but size does not matter here. The customers usually go for a quick meal, but it's always better to take-out.However, if you do take-out, you might have to wait a while before getting your food. The kitchen is doing what they can to get your food as fast as possible but you will have to wait.

They have a very special gravy that tastes so good! We were in Montreal for 3 days and we had their poutine every day. Still graving for some more! However, it's a bit too pricey compared to the size.

Forget about La Banquise. THIS is the best poutine you will find in Montreal. The fries are really crispy and gravy is great. Have a burger while you're at it too. Tiny spot with about 6 bar stools and 3, 2 person high top tables. Best hole in the wall I've ever found!

Lost my poutine virginity here...loved it! Could be eating their poutine all day long, but particularly great if you're looking for comfort food after a cold, tiring day. Burger was awesome as well - small, simple but delicious. The whole meal + a drink was only $12 CAD. Would come back for the tofu burger another day.

I've tried Patati Patata twice and I still don't really understand the hype about this place. Ive had their burgers and their poutine and both just taste as ordinary as it gets. However, I must say that the prices are quite cheap and if you are looking for something cheap and fast, this might be the place for you. Otherwise, there are plenty of great places around.

I really don't know what is the big deal about the poutine in this place. Honestly I had better - considering the price and the taste, I think McDonald poutine (when they had it back in Vancouver) is better value.Now the burgers... I dont know about this mustard - it's not subtle at all - It's way too overpowering considering meat to bun ratio.  In this case, I think I would opt to eat five guys instead.  Good try though.  Luckily we got sandwiches from omnivore at the same time so... We were satisfied overall that night with our choice of food.

After waking up with the mother of all hangovers, and quite possibly still drunk, we were ravenous. Patati patata saved our Saturday with an amazing and inexpensive breakfast. The service was warm and friendly, and the food was outstanding. We highly recommend this place. Thank you guys.

This was the perfect spot for me when I was working until 10pm and commuting home across town. I'd drop by here with an appetite big enough to cause a disturbance in the Force, and just squeak in before the 11pm closing time (they've since extended those hours). I'd trundle in, covered in a disgusting layer of sweat from sprinting on my bike to make it in time.Fish burger assiette, s'il-te-plait. Poutine, salade.Meanwhile, you can watch a paltry staff of two fill all the orders in fascination in a tiny shoebox of a kitchen while you sit at the bar, contemplating life, and being baptized by the oily fumes wafting in your face. Please don't ever change, Patati.

This is by far my favourite poutine place in Montreal. The portions aren't overwhelming and are priced appropriately. The fries are nice and crispy, the cheese curds squeaky, and the gravy just simply divine.I usually get the patatine, but keep in mind that the mushrooms, onions, and peppers are raw (I like it that way but I have friends who don't). If you're still hungry, their fish sliders are also really great, and only $3!Most importantly though, is that they're open until 2am, and it tastes even better when you're drunk!!

The burger was fabulous, including the bread. I am glad we chose this place. You are given a paper to mark down everything you want on your burger and it is kade to order. Service was good and fast. It was exactly what we were looking for- a quick and tasty dinner before heading back to our hotel after a long day.

New Jersey to Montreal just for the poutine and this place satiated my desperation and craving! AMAZing service! It's a very small place - can hardly seat 10 at a time. It gets very crowded at lunch. Definitely try the patatine!

we were excited to come here as we kept passing it on our strolls, the food was unremarkable, the beer was really good; however, their service was rushed and angry. in this industry (also in such a tiny shop) this makes all the difference. the man at the cash register was annoyed and loudly tried to tell me "how service works in North America" all over a misunderstanding. I'm an Asian American born and raised in North America and that comment was a slap in the face. I don't know where he might have thought I was from but does that matter? thumbs down for ignorance and poutine that was mediocre at best. thumbs up for beer and beer only (since it probably made me docile enough to tolerate inexcusable behavior from the staff)

Self-proclaimed poutine-obsessed girl checking in. On my latest visit to Montreal my friend had the challenge of bringing me the best poutine in the area. I was in town for three days and was getting nervous when our schedules didn't match up on the first two days. However, the stars aligned on day three and I ended up with warm take-out poutine from Patati Patata in my hands. While this was actually my friend's second favorite poutine place, he thought I would prefer it over the other. He ordered me one with peppers, onions, and shaved beef. I usually opt for the traditional but I'm glad he forced me to go beyond that. The fries were crunchy on their own, but gave way to the gravy and became softer. This may sound bad, but I like when the fries can absorb the gravy without becoming mushy. The cheese curds were the perfect temperature even after traveling. The outside of each nugget was just starting to become warm and gooey while the inside left a cooler, squeakier end to the bite. All of the toppings worked together. I especially enjoyed the fresh and colorful peppers. I'm so used to poutine being different versions of brown, but the red and yellow peppers made the visual experience of my meal quite pleasurable. I can't say anything to the interior of the building, service, or really anything besides this one dish, but my poutine senses were thrilled and I could go back to the states a happy girl.

The national junk food dish of Canada is undoubtedly poutine, the love child of gravy and cheese kurds and a potato concoction worthy of countless heart attacks.  After many encounters of this nearly banned food (#1), I'm willing to admit one of the best versions I've ever had was here at Patati Patata.This greasy spoon has a stellar reputation for serving Montreal some of the very best in comfort fare for little money.  It's been insanely crowded here almost every time I've been here and is not a place for anyone who is remotely claustrophobic.  A 15 person occupancy might be too generous of a number, but it's pretty tight in here regardless.  There is barely enough for 4 on their counter, and I've seen some folks literally just stand and eat their food.  I've been fortunate enough to score a seat each time, but that wasn't without having to wait at least 20 minutes.Their burgers are good, juicy and flavorful in every bite.  Also good are their daily soups, which in my recent case was a red beet borscht - totally worth all $2 of my money.  What most folks come for is what everyone should try, their amazing poutine.  Cheese kurds sprinkled over a bed of gravy soaked fries, makes for the kind of artery clogging "salad" that looks more like a stew of potatoes.  Every bite was savory, the gravy was delightful, and the cheese kurds were not in the least bit heavy.  Best of all, it cost me only $4.00 for a bowl of poutine goodness.Like only the finest of Montreal businesses, they're open fairly late.  Usually till 11PM and as late as midnight on the weekends.  Be it for breakfast or a late night anti-hangover meal or even (read: especially) a poutine craving, Patati Patata is the place to be.  _______(#1)  They tried to ban this at sporting events in an effort to become healthier and nothing like their southern neighbor.  Whatever, I've got two words:  universal healthcare.
One of my favorites of all favorites: burgers and poutine. Sweet guys, very Montreal spot, pretty charming.

This is a cute little place with decent prices. Emphasis on little. And cute. That included some of the staff but I digress. I had a hamburger and poutine and my sister opted for a poutine with veggies. Everything was great except that maybe they forgot it was a veggie poutine until the very end or they just did not ask. The cook threw all the veggies on the poutine raw (mushrooms, peppers, onions) which I thought was odd. We finished and my sister said it was "ok" and as we were paying, I noticed someone else had the same thing and they were GRILLING the veggies before putting them on the poutine. No big deal but that is the difference between a 4 and 5 star rating I guess.

My cousin and her boyfriend took the friend and I to this tiny diner on Saint Laurent for lunch. The phrase "Patati Patata" is similar to "Hakuna Matata" from what I was told. The diner is this really cute and small place with an outgoing staff. They sell basic fast food items at super cheap prices! I opted for one hamburger and some fries with sauce. The burger was slider-size, which was why it was only $2.50. One of the employees told me that people usually order two to have their fill. If you decide to order a burger, you get a slip of paper to check off the toppings and sauces that you want on it. I liked their fries because they were done fresh. My friend, who got the fries without the sauce, told me the sauce made them taste saltier (I personally couldn't tell).Patati Patata is a very casual place and great for a quick meal for any time of the day. You wouldn't go out of your way to visit it but if you want something fast and cheap, this is the place to be! Definitely drop by if you are ever on Saint Laurent and looking for some light to eat.
One word ladies, DALOISH. Cheap eats, cheap beer, nice people! It's a bit small but soooo worth squeezing ya cute butt in there.
Adorable little restaurant. Casual, tiny, great service. Burgers are little, but was great. Fries are perfect. Yum

Was a good sign when we got out of our taxi and the cute old driver gave us a happy little wave and shouted "I come here quite often myself - enjoy your lunch!"Extremely cramped space but wonderfully attentive & friendly staff who try their best to cater to their customers in the space they have to work with.  Menu was simple & straightforward.  The food tasted fresh and the price was fantastic!  I got the hamburger avec fromage and added the poutine & salade.  The gravy on the poutine was savory and delightful.  The hamburger hit the spot.My husband got the BLT and really enjoyed it - commented on how good the bread was.  We also got an extra order of the vegetable poutine. Everyone eating in there was happy - super chill vibe.  Lovely place - we would definitely come back if we were looking for a simple little sandwich & poutine fix.
Very mediocre poutine.Wasn't even hot, the cheese never even had a chance to melt. The gravy was not that great.Have had a tastier poutine at the A&W on the saskatchewan border. Strange...

Great late night spot if you're feeling for some greasy food after a night of drinking. Located on St Laurent and the venue is quite tiny. Can only sit an average of 8 to 10 people at a time. Most people do take out though. I came here for the sole purpose of poutine!! Definitely enjoyed it. Fries were thin cut and the curds were extra squeaky. The gravy is on the little salter side but definitely worth the calories here! For 6$ before tax you get a whooping amount of poutine. Servers and owner are also super friendly guys

Such good poutine! The gravy is vegetarian which is a plus for me. Perfect portion, perfect prices. They serve beer and other things such as tofu burgers, real burgers, borcht, etc. It's very, very, busy during evenings or late night Thursday, Friday , Saturday... so expect that you're not going to find a table when you stumble in from your weird university clubbing night out. That being said, during the week it's reasonable to find a spot to sit and the people who work there are nice and work hard.

Service was horrible. The person behind the counter was talking about us to someone else in French. He thought we didn't understand, but we speak the language. I will never again go here and will advise people not to eat the food or step foot inside this hellhole.

I had their regular poutine and I didn't like it too much. The gravy was sour (not that it went bad or anything) because of the olives. I loved the atmosphere of the store though, it's really small but they're really quick to serve you since the seats are limited. Many people get a takeout here because of that. But the rotation is so quick that we found seats quite immediately. Overall, it didn't make a lasting impression on me, especially in terms of the food quality.

This is a nice place to stop in for a quick bite to eat! I enjoyed the poutine, though the olive flavor was a bit odd, as other reviewers pointed out. I also got a burger, which was very small, which I probably should have suspected due to the price. Overall it was good, but nothing spectacular.

Had my last lunch here before moving out of my apartment in the lower plateau to one downtown, closer to school-- it was a really sad day. This cramped little dive always has a line up and let me tell you: worth the wait.The space: Well to cut it short: there is none.The vibe: Very friendly, super chill(despite the busy-ness), lots of locals.The main event:That poutine is to die for. I don't know how they keep the fries crispy BUT THEY DO. And that gravy: it's like the world's most heavenly foodgasm in your mouth. I kid you not, I've never tried a gravy that delicious in my life. Words cannot fathom the magic that sizzles into your life when that first drop of gravy hits your tongue. It's-- it's-- you just HAVE to try it. The cheese curds: now, I'm no French cheese genius, but the cheese curds are good here too. (Disclaimer: I actually can't tell the difference between good cheese curds and great cheese curds. I only know if it's good or bad and Patati Patata hits the spot).The price:Cheap and I love it.Writing this review makes me homesick for their mouthwateringly delicious poutine and the plateau vibes. Maybe I'll see you guys there soon :")

Yeah so I used to live almost right next door and I miss those guys, the plates are generous and it is cheap.It is tiny, less than 20 seats.The burgers at Patati are smaller burgers that you would normally have in other restaurants, which is perfect because the price is also small.You can eat there or take it to go, no reservations of course!! I recommend the poutine patatine or Tofu burgers plate. Oh and the breakfast eggs. Most of the time, there is a line-up outside so be patient!I can't wait to go back!!

Was dying for some poutine when in Montréal this weekend and theirs fell a little short.  Although I like olives, I found the olive taste to be a little strange.  It added that tartness to it as though you were dabbing it with some malt vinegar but if that's the case, I would've just dabbed it with malt vinegar.  The shoestring fries were perfectly crisp though. The amount of curds were pretty generous and the gravy was still pretty good. If I had the opportunity to find another reputable poutinerie within walking distance with my group, I would've tried to find another place.  3/5.

After trying to eat here for a few times, I finally got into the restaurant without having to lineup outside.I got a bacon cheese burger and poutine for 11 something dollars, which is ok pricing.The burger had the size of a slider. You know the little round bread you get in big packages at costco? Yeh, I fear that is the bread they use. The meat patty fit well into the bun, which means it's probably the size of a 1.59$ mcdonald's hamburger patty. Except, it was well cooked and tasty. So...it's kind of worth the 2.75$ basic burger + 0.65$ cheese + 0.65$ bacon? You tell me.When I inquired about the poutine, two ladies at the counter vouched for it. The portion was ok, just enough to keep me interested throughout (I get bored real quick). The gravy was very salty, but had a particular taste (that I can't seem to place, probably because of the beer I had priorly), perhaps mushroom based, which differentiates it from a generic gravy. There was a bit too much cheese however, in terms of proportion. My last bites mainly consisted of unmelted cheese. But it does go 'squeak squeak' when I chew hahaha.I'm not a particular fan of their fries, which is sad to say, because I'd assume a restaurant calling itself 'Patati Patata' would have a great potato recipe. They were crispy but brown (gives off a bitter taste) on the outside and thinly cut so the resulting fries are rather dry (not enough of interior fluffy content).Purely in terms of taste, I'd give 4/5 for the burger, 3/5 for the poutine. Can someone, who's not a tourist eating poutine for the first time, explain to me what I am missing out?

I came 15 minutes before close but because the dirty hipster couldn't process orders from the group in front of me in time I wasnt able to order. At that point everything else around was closed. I have never experienced such pathetic service, but such is Montreal. I would never go back not recommend. Find a better alternative for cheap food.

I was ecstatic to try the poutine from Patati Patata because my brother said it was the best in town. To my disappointment, definitely not the best in town.... limp little soggy fries with hard cheese curds and thick poutine sauce topped with an olive is a big NO to be. just NO. will not recommend and will definitely not be able here. FIY the place is tiny !

This was my go-to breakfast spot while on my mini get-away. I was recommended this place by a friend and it did not disappoint. Food and service were superb! Customer service was excellent - the guys were so nice and friendly. The price of the food were acceptable - not dirt cheap but not ridiculously expensive - I'd say it's averagely priced. While the place is a bit small, the vibe of the restaurant is great. Only complaint - although I did not bring it to their attention - was that my last meal there had a long thick black hair tangled in my bacon (if you zoom into my picture - you can see the strand of hair over the eggs, orange and bacon on the right) :( I'm not easily grossed out and I know this happens so I let it pass. All in all - great cute place on a budget. Will definitely come by again when I'm back in Montreal!
One of the best tofu scramble plate in Montreal!!! The staff are nice and friendly, Ill try to come back definitely!!

So, at first you see its small. If they're busy, its crowded and a small line leads out front. EVEN with that against us, we waited and ordered and MAN was it worth it.First, the gentleman who took our order was friendly and courteous. He helped us decide on our food since it was our first time there.We ended up with a small variety that included the poutine and their Mediterranean Burger. BOTH WERE DELICIOUS!If you are in the area, make sure you try the Poutine..it really is that good!
Outstanding burger.  Excellent poutine.  Super nice owner and staff.  Great prices.
Cute little Resto and very nice waiters .I would give it 4 stars if they can do better with their hygiene problem

Such a great little place. Limited seating but I've never had to wait for a table. The service was excellent, even though they were very busy. The poutine is perfect. The regular is just as tasty as the one with onions, peppers and mushrooms. We also had a burger, grilled cheese and onion soup. All were good but the poutine was the stand out dish. Would highly recommend. Great spot for people watching. Also, cheap beer!
Tasty burgers. Crepes are not so impressive but overall experience is great. Might be long wait cuz it is really small.

This little hole in the wall is a DEFINITE MUST TRY at the St Laurent Blvd area. The Cheeseburger with bacon burger slider was very moist and juicy.  Poutine was the best we ever had and the desserts are AMAZING!!! It was our first time to try the Rein Elisabeth which is a sweet date cake with a nice frosting... It was so good; My husband was still looking for it the next morning!!! Their brownie is VERY decadent; very well done, Patati Patata... You've made new fans here!!It's in the same strip as Schwartz but trust me.. You won't regret coming here!

If you can get a seat in this tiny place you're in for a treat (cheap treat though). I love the open kitchen concept, and the cosy feeling inside. Burgers, salads, fries and poutine are all great here.

I love this place. It is SO Montreal. The poutine is reliably great, and they serve beer. Mostly though, I love the atmosphere- so European- a tiny little place with people squeezed in along the counter and at a few small tables, real people who obviously enjoy working there making yummy food, and nightlife buzzing by outside. Cosy and delicious!!!

Patati and Patata is in a prime location on the corner of st Laurent  and Rachel. The poutine has a homemade sauce  that has a sweet like aftertaste. The fresh cut French fries are fried not too crispy but not too soft, in other words, PERFECTION.  With a generous amount of cheese curds, to satisfy any cheese lover.  An important tip is to always get a salad with the poutine, (it's almost the same price) . The salads have a nice variety of greens, its a colorful salad,  orange and yellow peppers, onions, olives,  with a crispy leafy lettuce chopped to bite size.The salad also comes With the choice 4 different house dressing, my favorite is the balsamic.The fish filet is made to order, they cook everything right in front of you, on a nice fluffy roll . The filet of sole tasted fresh, moist and succulent. There is something to be said about a fish being prepared in front of you also the food is package conveniently for people on the go like myself.

It's cheap. It's hearty. It's friendly. It's wonderful. For someone who loves burgers and fries, I can't believe it took me 8 years to try Patati Patata. In my defence, Pitarifique is right across the street. But needless to say, I'm now hooked. Breakfast, lunch or dinner, you can't go wrong with this spot. It's a bit cozy, and you may wait for a table, but it's totally worth it.

Classic poutine in Montreal! A must try for visitors looking to try this classic dish. Small area for seating inside so don't go with large group or consider take out. Burgers are also good if you want a more full meal. Prices are very reasonable to better than other poutine competitors in the city.

1 star not for the food experience but the service my fiancée and I received from the bearded guy at the register, not only wasn't he welcoming ( the way he spoke to us had a vibe of "don't stay here, we have other people coming" but at the end he overcharged me by almost 10 dollars, I noticed the mistake once I got out, came back and confronted him. He acted as if it wasn't his fault but ultimately admitted to the mistake and I got my money back. Food was delicious but I won't come back because of that prick. The other two guys were super cool.

Food: 3/3 Service/ambiance: 1/2The food here was very good. Also, the cost for the amount of food you get is great! They really pack your plate. Staff are very friendly, my only minus is that the place is cramped and can't hold many, but either wise, I was very satisfied with this place.
I like their vegetable poutine. Compared to the same one in La Banquise, this one is more fresh and less heavy.

Flying in from Southern California and arriving late in Montreal, this is the perfect place to get your poutine fix.  It's open late, they serve beer, and the types of poutine are abundant. If it's crowded, order to go and chill at the park across the street.

Very tiny old-school diner type. Packed when we were there. Poutine seems to be the specialty and it was delicious. Service was friendly and funny. Local crowd was having a great time. Menu also had hamburgers and hotdogs I believe. A few local beers on tap that we tried were in the "okay" range. Great for people watching.

Amazing hole in the wall type place to get some fantastic poutine and mini burgers and beer. I've also had the BLT and it's great. I recommend the combination plate of Burger (or BLT) + poutine + salad. Unreal.

We were very hungry and after a trying day in Montreal and were on the search for a decent bite (on a Monday night) that wouldn't break the bank. After a long walk and still no decision, we decided to try it. My son had all three types of burgers and the poutine. He really enjoyed the regular burger and we both loved the tofu with hummus. The poutine was ok, but the five stars is for the tofu burger!

Waiting right now in line for more than 30 min, not even exagerating, stuck between loud and noisy people since the place is so small, and just been told that they gave my order to someone else ??????? Worst service ever, never ever coming back here. This can't be serious...

The restaurant is small but good. All the staff were very friendly and price was reasonable. I just ordered one classic poutine to go. The food was made freshly and gravy was hot enough to melt the cheese curd. However, it seemed to be a little salty for me. Maybe it was not my dish. I preferred some kind of creative-style poutine~ I found that many customers chosen their burger. It looks good too.

Love this place. I cannot believe it took me this long to review it. Everything on their menu is delicious. My favorite is the fish burger. If you want a great home made ice tea, get it here. It is a tiny place, always busy so expect to wait for a bit but it is worth it. Some of my friends claim, this is the best Poutine in town.

Little cheeseburger slider with salad and fries: A. Side of poutine: B. No squeaks to be had, and the gravy was a bit thin. Fries were excellent.Really liked the quick, friendly service and the whole set up.
Crazy good poutine, friendliest service around, and reasonable prices. Will return next time I'm in Montreal. #PoutineIsLife

SO GOOD!!!! DRUNK 10/10! FAST! GOOD CURDAGE!  As a Quebecer, you get authentic poutine for a cheap price. perfect to share with a friend, especially for the price if you're clubbing on St-Laurent. recommend!

user_name: Yelp Was Supposed To Delete This K.
user_review: The poutine here was ultimately delicious: really beefy gravy, really fresh (and delightfully squeaky) cheese curd, REALLY crispy fries. I was probably too amused that my 32-oz serving of beer came in an adorable demi pitcher that belongs in a dollhouse.

Great sliders, fries, and poutine.This little greasyspoon lunch counter has some of the tastiest burgers in the city, and while they're closer in size to sliders, the price is perfectly right whether you want to have one or two. They also make great tofu and fish burgers, too.Of course, no greasyspoon is complete without good fries, and their julien fries are some of the best in the city. I'd suggest trying your choice of one or two burgers with the fries/salad plate, but upgrading the fries to a poutine is a pretty solid idea, too. There are a number of other French Canadian classics on the menu, ranging from shepherd's pie to (all day) greasy breakfast, that are all worth trying, so return visits are highly recommended if you're really high quality diner fare.The only challenge is that seating is very limited, so you might want to consider takeout if you mind waiting a few minutes for a spot.
Got my first Poutine here, and it was very good!This is my kind of place. It's small, affordable, fun urban decoration and the friendly staff serves good food.
Pretty cheap and fast. Perfect for after hitting a couple bars. I went there with some friends to sober up before heading home

This teensy, adorable restaurant was recommended to me by a friend who lives locally. After driving Ny to Montreal, we were hankering for something good to nosh on.This place has awesome poutine! The gravy is hot and somewhat melts the cheese curds all over your fries. Fabulous! Who wouldn't like that? I had the classic poutine for $5.50CAD and boyfriend got a slight variation with patatine, which also had mushrooms, onions, and peppers. We both loved what we got.Best of all, the place is very reasonably priced. Boyfriend and I went back a second time for more poutine, a grilled cheese, BLT, and a burger. These burgers are $2.50, with a piece of paper and pencil for you to cross off what you want on your burger. Wonderful. Anything that helps me write down exactly what I want and not have to describe to the cooks that I want a little of this and a little of that- is all welcome in my book. Speaking of which, the young guys who work there are all really friendly, attentive, and even though they were very busy, gave us great recommendations and instructions for local things to do. Great spot!

Patati Patata has some of the freshest and most flavorful fast food money can buy in Montreal. When I think of where I'd like to eat in Montreal, or I'm recommending a restaurant to friends, this place always comes up. So far I've tried their hamburgers, hot dogs, fries, poutine and their homemade iced tea. Honestly, there's nothing I can say that can adequately describe how good the food is here, you just need to go and see for yourself.

Maybe we were a bit spoiled by having Au Pied de Cochon's poutine days before coming to Patati Patata.  The poutine here is way too salty. The fries were too over fried and over salted, the gravy was too salty as well-- so much that there was not "gravy" taste in the gravy.  The cheese curds were in bits too small that don't provide the "squeak" texture you would expect in a poutine.  However, the people are wonderful here, both the staff and the customers.  Maybe the great company is what keeps this place a popular one, and maybe their other food items are great, but I came here only wanting to find out the taste of their poutine.

I love this tiny spot!There's just something so old fashion about this greasy spoon. It's very small, and only run by 2 people at a time, but they are surprisingly efficient. I've only had the burgers and poutines, which are very tasty. My friend loves the fish burger. They even sell beer. Hey... what more do you want. Reasonable prices? They have those as well.
